name: Deposit containers, at collection, California Refund Value, CRV
description:
This attributional unit process LCI represents electricity and fuel requirements for fuel use per kg of material collected via California refund value (CRV) system. The LCI study was conducted by Franklin Associates, Ltd. and sponsored jointly by NAPCOR, the American Chemistry Council (ACC), the Association of Postconsumer Plastic Recyclers (APR), and the PET Resin Association (PETRA). Using life cycle inventory (LCI) methodology, the study determines and quantifies the energy requirements, solid wastes, and atmospheric and waterborne emissions for the processes required to collect postconsumer PET and HDPE packaging, sort and separate the material, and reprocess it into clean recycled resin.

Important note: although most of the data in the US LCI database has undergone some sort of review, the database as a whole has not yet undergone a formal validation process. Please email comments to lci@nrel.gov.
category: 56: Administrative and Support and Waste Management and Remediation Services/5621: Waste Collection

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data compiled 2010 from most recent sources
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Typical  transport and baling of accumulated deposit containers recovered via California refund value (CRV) system
processDocumentation.inventoryMethodDescription: Attributional; data sets for the three recycling unit processes (collection, sorting/separation, reclaimer operations) were linked to cover the full sequence of processing steps required to produce recycled resins ï‚® gate-to-gate results; for cradle-to-gate LCI of recycled resin, the practitioner needs to make decision about virgin resin burdens associated with the postconsumer products that are feedstocks to recycling. Recycling occurs in the context of a product made from resin; use and end-of-life management of the material will depend on the product in which it is used
processDocumentation.modelingConstantsDescription: Based on information provided by a confidential source, transport of deposit containers to the IPC is modeled as a volume-limited load of loose bottles transported by a tractor-trailer truck. The distance is estimated as 150 miles, and a fuel economy of 6.5 mpg is used for the truck from http://www.bts.gov/publications/national_transportation_statistics/excel/table_04_14.xls.  At the IPC or MRF some additional sorting may be done before the resin is baled for shipment to the next processing location.
processDocumentation.completenessDescription:
TREATMENT OF MISSING ENVIRONMENTAL DATA
Elementary flows are cut-off at less than 1% based on environmental relevance.

TREATMENT OF MISSING TECHNOSPHERE DATA
Intermediate flows are cut-off at less than 1% based on environmental relevance. Capital equipment is not included in this unit process.

MASS BALANCE
Includes weight of co-collected wastes later removed at reclaimer.
processDocumentation.dataSelectionDescription: Similar to the deposit dropoff system, no consumer transport burdens are assigned to postconsumer plastic recovered through the CRV program or from commercial sources. For this scenario, transport of bottles from the site to an IPC or to a material recovery facility (MRF) is also based on a volume-limited shipment of loose bottles; however, it is assumed that the accumulated quantities transported per pickup are larger so that a tractor-trailer truck is used , with a fuel economy of 6.5 mpg.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Assumtions and calculations described in Modeling Constants.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS
The system boundary includes the commercial transport of accumulated quantities of containers recovered for recycling through a collection program such as the California dposit system for California Refund Value (CRV) from collection point to an intermediate processing center (IPC) and baling of the containers at the IPC for shipment to the next processing location.

DATA COLLECTION
Assumptions and calculations are described in Modeling Constants and the supporting documentation.

UNCERTAINTY ESTIMATION
No uncertainty estimations were included.
processDocumentation.dataCollectionDescription: Data compiled 2010 from most recent sources

sources.name: Franklin Associates (2011) LCI HDPE & PET Recycled Resin

reviews.details: The LCI study was conducted by Franklin Associates, Ltd. and sponsored jointly by NAPCOR, the American Chemistry Council (ACC), the Association of Postconsumer Plastic Recyclers (APR), and the PET Resin Association (PETRA). Using life cycle inventory (LCI) methodology, the study determines and quantifies the energy requirements, solid wastes, and atmospheric and waterborne emissions for the processes required to collect postconsumer PET and HDPE packaging, sort and separate the material, and reprocess it into clean recycled resin. The data has had a partial critical review by internal parties.

processDocumentation.intendedApplication: "Accounting, with system-external interactions" - The intended application is a purely descriptive accounting / documentation of the analysed system including existing interactions with other systems in the LCI model.
processDocumentation.projectDescription: LIFE CYCLE INVENTORY OF 100% POSTCONSUMER HDPE AND PET RECYCLED RESIN FROM POSTCONSUMER CONTAINERS AND PACKAGING PREPARED FOR THE PLASTICS DIVISION OF THE AMERICAN CHEMISTRY COUNCIL, INC. THE ASSOCIATION OF POSTCONSUMER PLASTIC RECYCLERS (APR), THE NATIONAL ASSOCIATION FOR PET CONTAINER RESOURCES (NAPCOR), AND THE PET RESIN ASSOCIATION (PETRA) BY FRANKLIN ASSOCIATES, A DIVISION OF ERG PRAIRIE VILLAGE, KANSAS JANUARY 19, 2011.
